speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: SCENE I. The heath.

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: Enter EDGAR

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Yet better thus, and known to be contemn'd,

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Than still contemn'd and flatter'd. To be worst,

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune,

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear:

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: The lamentable change is from the best;

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: The worst returns to laughter. Welcome, then,

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace!

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Owes nothing to thy blasts. But who comes here?

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER, led by an Old Man

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: My father, poorly led? World, world, O world!

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee,

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Lie would not yield to age.

speaker: Old Man
text_entry: O, my good lord, I have been your tenant, and

speaker: Old Man
text_entry: your father's tenant, these fourscore years.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Away, get thee away; good friend, be gone:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thy comforts can do me no good at all;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thee they may hurt.

speaker: Old Man
text_entry: Alack, sir, you cannot see your way.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I have no way, and therefore want no eyes;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I stumbled when I saw: full oft 'tis seen,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Our means secure us, and our mere defects

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Prove our commodities. O dear son Edgar,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The food of thy abused father's wrath!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Might I but live to see thee in my touch,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'ld say I had eyes again!

speaker: Old Man
text_entry: How now! Who's there?

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: [Aside]  O gods! Who is't can say 'I am at

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: the worst'?

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: I am worse than e'er I was.

speaker: Old Man
text_entry: 'Tis poor mad Tom.

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: [Aside]  And worse I may be yet: the worst is not

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: So long as we can say  'This is the worst.'

speaker: Old Man
text_entry: Fellow, where goest?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is it a beggar-man?

speaker: Old Man
text_entry: Madman and beggar too.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He has some reason, else he could not beg.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I' the last night's storm I such a fellow saw;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which made me think a man a worm: my son

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Came then into my mind; and yet my mind

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Was then scarce friends with him: I have heard

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: more since.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As flies to wanton boys, are we to the gods.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: They kill us for their sport.

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: [Aside] How should this be?

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Bad is the trade that must play fool to sorrow,

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Angering itself and others.--Bless thee, master!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is that the naked fellow?

speaker: Old Man
text_entry: Ay, my lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then, prithee, get thee gone: if, for my sake,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou wilt o'ertake us, hence a mile or twain,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I' the way toward Dover, do it for ancient love;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And bring some covering for this naked soul,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Who I'll entreat to lead me.

speaker: Old Man
text_entry: Alack, sir, he is mad.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: 'Tis the times' plague, when madmen lead the blind.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Do as I bid thee, or rather do thy pleasure;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Above the rest, be gone.

speaker: Old Man
text_entry: I'll bring him the best 'parel that I have,

speaker: Old Man
text_entry: Come on't what will.

speaker: Old Man
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sirrah, naked fellow,--

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Poor Tom's a-cold.

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Aside

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: I cannot daub it further.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Come hither, fellow.

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: [Aside]  And yet I must.--Bless thy sweet eyes, they bleed.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Know'st thou the way to Dover?

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Both stile and gate, horse-way and foot-path. Poor

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Tom hath been scared out of his good wits: bless

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: thee, good man's son, from the foul fiend! five

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: fiends have been in poor Tom at once; of lust, as

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Obidicut; Hobbididence, prince of dumbness; Mahu, of

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: stealing; Modo, of murder; Flibbertigibbet, of

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: mopping and mowing, who since possesses chambermaids

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: and waiting-women. So, bless thee, master!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Here, take this purse, thou whom the heavens' plagues

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Have humbled to all strokes: that I am wretched

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Makes thee the happier: heavens, deal so still!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That slaves your ordinance, that will not see

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Because he doth not feel, feel your power quickly;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So distribution should undo excess,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And each man have enough. Dost thou know Dover?

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Ay, master.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: There is a cliff, whose high and bending head

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Looks fearfully in the confined deep:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Bring me but to the very brim of it,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And I'll repair the misery thou dost bear

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: With something rich about me: from that place

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I shall no leading need.

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Give me thy arm:

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Poor Tom shall lead thee.

speaker: EDGAR
text_entry: Exeunt
